description: From Middle English volume, from Old French volume, from Latin volūmen (“book, roll”), from volvō (“roll, turn about”).

entries.meaning: A three-dimensional measure of space that comprises a length, a width and a height. It is measured in units of cubic centimeters in metric, cubic inches or cubic feet in English measurement.
examples: The room is 9x12x8, so its volume is 864 cubic feet.
The proper products can improve your hair's volume.
Please turn down the volume on the stereo.
Volume can be measured in decibels.

entries.meaning: The issues of a periodical over a period of one year.
examples: I looked at this week's copy of the magazine. It was volume 23, issue 45.

entries.meaning: A single book of a publication issued in multi-book format, such as an encyclopedia.
examples: The letter "G" was found in volume 4.

entries.meaning: (in the plural, by extension) A great amount (of meaning) about something.
(obsolete) A roll or scroll, which was the form of ancient books.

examples: The volume of ticket sales decreased this week.

entries.meaning: (economics) The total supply of money in circulation or, less frequently, total amount of credit extended, within a specified national market or worldwide.
(computing) An accessible storage area with a single file system, typically resident on a single partition of a hard disk.
(bodybuilding) The total of weight worked by a muscle in one training session, the weight of every single repetition summed up.
examples: (key muscle growth stimuli) Coordinate terms: mechanical tension, frequency

verbs.description: volume (third-person singular simple present volumes, present participle voluming, simple past and past participle volumed)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be conveyed through the air, waft.
examples: […]  thumping guns and pattering musket-shots, the long big boom of surgent hosts, and the muffled voluming and crash of storm-bells, proclaimed that the insurrection was hot.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to move through the air, waft.
examples: We lay leaning over the bows, now looking up at the mist blown in never-ending volumed sheets, now at the sail swelling in the wind before which it fled, and again down at the water through which our boat was ploughing its evanescent furrow.
